content_en:
ЁЯСС
Successors of the Mauryas

The Shunga Empire was founded by Pushyamitra Shunga in 185 BCE by assassinating the last Mauryan emperor Brihadratha. Pushyamitra, who was a Mauryan general (senapati), re-established Brahmanical rule on the throne of Magadha. Their capital was Pataliputra, but later Vidisha (Madhya Pradesh) became a major cultural center.

ЁЯЫбя╕П
Resistance to Yavana Invasions

The Shunga period is known for Indo-Greek (Yavana) invasions of India. Pushyamitra successfully repelled the attacks of Greek kings like Demetrius and possibly Menander, and asserted his sovereignty by performing Ashwamedha sacrifices.

ЁЯОи
Cultural Renaissance

Although Pushyamitra is described as anti-Buddhist in Buddhist texts, archaeological evidence (such as the Bharhut Stupa and the railings of Sanchi) suggests that Buddhist art continued to flourish during the Shunga period. This era witnessed the revival of Sanskrit language (Mahabhashya of Patanjali) and Hindu law (Manusmriti).
